# Fall Report {#Fall}

This report shows trends in water quality, plankton, and fish across multiple IEP 
surveys for September through November from 1966 to `r report_year`.

***

## Delta Outflow {#fall-outflow}

:::: {.row}
::: {.col-1-outflow}
- Freshwater flow influences water quality, plankton, and fish populations.
- Fall flow is driven primarily by upstream dam releases and exports.
- `r getCaption(outflow_fall)`
:::

::: {.col-2-outflow}
```{r echo=FALSE, fig.cap="mean is represented by a dotted red line"}
knitr::include_graphics(file.path(fig_root_static,"mline.svg"))
```
:::{.expand}
```{r fig.cap=getAlttext(outflow_fall), echo=FALSE}
getPlot(outflow_fall)
```
:::
:::
::::

***

## Secchi Depth {#fall-secchi}

### Background {.unlisted .unnumbered}

:::: {.row}
::: {.col-1-background}
* Organisms in this ecosystem are adapted to high turbidity conditions, and reductions in turbidity can have many negative ecological effects.
* Higher values for Secchi depth indicate lower turbidity.
* Secchi depth is measured monthly by DWR’s [Environmental Monitoring Program](https://emp.baydeltalive.com/wiki/12297) by dropping a black-and-white disk in the water until it disappears.
:::

::: {.col-2-background}
```{r fig.height=10, fig.align="center", fig.cap="image of a secchi disk", echo=FALSE}
knitr::include_graphics(file.path(fig_root_static,"secchidisc.png"))
```
:::
::::

## Water Temperature {#fall-temp}

### Background {.unlisted .unnumbered}

:::: {.row}
::: {.col-1-background}
* Water temperature is monitored monthly by DWR’s [Environmental Monitoring Program](https://emp.baydeltalive.com/wiki/12297). 
* Fish growth and reproduction is highest in certain temperature ranges.
* Increasing fall temperatures may lower Delta Smelt reproduction.
* Fall temperatures are lower closer to the ocean and slightly higher in the Delta.
:::

::: {.col-2-background}

## Chlorophyll {#fall-chlorophyll}

### Background {.unlisted .unnumbered}

:::: {.row}
::: {.col-1-background}
* Chlorophyll is an indicator of phytoplankton production, which is low during the fall.
* Phytoplankton are the base of the pelagic food web. It is sampled monthly by DWR’s [Environmental Monitoring Program](https://emp.baydeltalive.com/wiki/12297).
* The invasion of the clam *Potamocorbula amurensis* caused a decline in phytoplankton and zooplankton after 1986 – especially in Suisun Bay.
:::

::: {.col-2-background}

## Zooplankton {#fall-zoop}

### Background {.unlisted .unnumbered}

:::: {.row}
::: {.col-1-background}
* Zooplankton is sampled monthly by the CDFW/DWR [Environmental Monitoring Program](https://emp.baydeltalive.com/wiki/12297) but sampling in San Pablo Bay did not begin until 1998. 
* Zooplankton are an important food source for pelagic fish. 
* Calanoid copepods and mysids are particularly good fish food. Cyclopoid copepods are not as good for fish food.
* Biomass in fall tends to be higher than winter, but lower than summer. 
:::

::: {.col-2-background}

## Fish {#fall-fish}

### Background {.unlisted .unnumbered}

* The Fall Midwater Trawl (FMWT) Survey began in 1967 and surveys the pelagic, or open water, fish community.  Indices for many pelagic fishes are at record lows, including Delta and Longfin Smelt, which are  protected by California and/or federal Endangered Species Acts.
* White Sturgeon is a species of concern and a popular target of recreational fishing. Catch per unit
effort is based on trammel net surveys.
* Fall-Run Chinook Salmon, an important species for both the commercial and recreational fishery, is  also a species of concern. Population dynamics are driven by hatchery production and a suite of  environmental variables. Totals counts of both in-river and hatchery returns are shown here.

## Recent Trends {#fall-recent}

### Background {.unlisted .unnumbered}

* Many pelagic fishes declined sharply around 2001 in what is known as the Pelagic Organism  Decline. Some species have continued to decline over the last 15 years.
* The [Fall Midwater Trawl Survey](https://wildlife.ca.gov/Conservation/Delta/Fall-Midwater-Trawl) was designed to sample age-0 striped bass, but has provided data on many additional species, including Delta Smelt and Longfin Smelt.
